body:
> Either fail the test or log a warning if both addResource() and overwriteConfigProperty() are used.

Maybe we initially use a warning and then soon make it an error?

> > Either fail the test or log a warning if both addResource() and overwriteConfigProperty() are used.
> 
> Maybe we initially use a warning and then soon make it an error?

Actually, something like this seems to work:
https://github.com/mkouba/quarkus/commit/1636cf4ee607ae6a3065a2aec1f96729016c6f1b

So we could merge the existing and overriden config properties.

The problem is that this fix could actually break existing tests :shrug:.
Yeah, it's probably better to move in a more safe direction, not a more lenient one.

> Yeah, it's probably better to move in a more safe direction, not a more lenient one.

Hm, I wouldn't call it "a more lenient one" but a "a convenient one".

The current behavior does not make a lot of sense because if an `addResource()` is used then `overrideConfigKey()` is ignored (due to the ShrinkWrap bug). So no _"override"_ really. If we log a warning we should also clarify the javadoc. But we'll have to say "override" does not mean "override" because of a bug and the behavior may change in the future -> complete mess. If we decide to fail the test then existing tests could fail and the behavior still makes no sense.

So I think that we should:
1. Merge the existing `application.properties` and the overriden properties
2. Clarify the javadoc that `overrideConfigKey()` is always preferred
3. Log a message that properties were merged + add an option to show the merged properties easily

> So I think that we should:
> 
>     1. Merge the existing `application.properties` and the overriden properties
> 
>     2. Clarify the javadoc that `overrideConfigKey()` is always preferred
> 
>     3. Log a message that properties were merged + add an option to show the merged properties easily

Makes sense to me, with one doubt though: if you contribute `application.properties` through both `addAsResource` and `withConfigurationResource`, then IMO merging these two files is dodgy. In case of conflict on one property key, which one would win? Are there even cases when we do that and it's not just a mistake? Wouldn't we want to completely ignore the one added though `addAsResource`?

To be clear:

* `.withConfigurationResource("...")` + `overrideConfigKey` => Fine (already works)
* `.addAsResource("...", "application.properties")` + `overrideConfigKey` => Fine (your patch would fix it)
* `.addAsResource("...", "application.properties")` + `.withConfigurationResource("...")` (with or without `overrideConfigKey`)  => Behavior is unclear, arguably dangerous

Also, I believe `.withConfigurationResource("...")` was initially added precisely because .addAsResource("...", "application.properties")` didn't work with `overrideConfigKey`, so... if you make it work, maybe `.withConfigurationResource("...")`  should be deprecated for removal?

> Makes sense to me, with one doubt though: if you contribute `application.properties` through both `addAsResource` and `withConfigurationResource`, then IMO merging these two files is dodgy. In case of conflict on one property key, which one would win? Are there even cases when we do that and it's not just a mistake? Wouldn't we want to completely ignore the one added though `addAsResource`?

That's a good point. I've never used `withConfigurationResource()` before so I forgot about this use case.

BTW `withConfigurationResource()` is backed by the same `Properties` object as `overrideConfigKey()`. So if you do `overrideConfigKey("foo","bar")` and then call `withConfigurationResource()` and the file contains `foo=baz` then the final value will be `foo=baz`. And if you call it the other way around the final value will be `foo=bar`.

>  .withConfigurationResource("...") + overrideConfigKey => Fine (already works)

Works but not ideally - see above. 

>   .addAsResource("...", "application.properties") + .withConfigurationResource("...") (with or without overrideConfigKey) 

Currently, the `withConfigurationResource("...")` properties would take precedence.

> Also, I believe .withConfigurationResource("...") was initially added precisely because .addAsResource("...", "application.properties")didn't work withoverrideConfigKey, so... if you make it work, maybe .withConfigurationResource("...")` should be deprecated for removal?

Good point again ;-). Because if you need to externalize the configuration in a file then something like `addAsResource("my-application.properties")` and `my-application.properties` located in `src/test/resources` work just fine.

Hm, and it seems that `QuarkusProdModeTest` is also affected.

Reading the method names, I would expect the following behaviours:

- `overrideConfigKey ` - max ordinal in the configuration key, overriding all available sources
- `withConfigurationResource` - above all the classpath resources, but not system properties or env.
- `addAsResource` - above all the classpath resources, but not system properties, env, and `withConfigurationResource`

You can combine all the APIs, and the ordinality should be clear.  Yes, current tests might likely break, and that is a problem.

We have inconsistencies in some places, that we should fix. Another one is the ordinality of `io.quarkus.test.junit.QuarkusTestProfile#getConfigOverrides`, which I would expect to have max ordinality, but it is being written as system properties. I am bringing this up so we can have a broader discussion. We may disagree on how we should order, but I think that at the very least, `overrideConfigKey` and `io.quarkus.test.junit.QuarkusTestProfile#getConfigOverrides` should be at the same ordinality.

@radcortez This issue is about `QuarkusUnitTest` (from `quarkus-junit5-internal`) which IMO does not reflect the `QuarkusTestProfile` at all.

> Reading the method names, I would expect the following behaviours:

Currently, all of these config properties are backed by the same `ConfigSource` - the one used to load `application.properties`. Which is probably not a problem because test authors control the deployment structure.

> 
>     * `overrideConfigKey ` - max ordinal in the configuration key, overriding all available sources
> 
>     * `withConfigurationResource` - above all the classpath resources, but not system properties or env.
> 
>     * `addAsResource` - above all the classpath resources, but not system properties, env, and `withConfigurationResource`
> 
> 
> You can combine all the APIs, and the ordinality should be clear. Yes, current tests might likely break, and that is a problem.
> 
> We have inconsistencies in some places, that we should fix. Another one is the ordinality of `io.quarkus.test.junit.QuarkusTestProfile#getConfigOverrides`, which I would expect to have max ordinality, but it is being written as system properties. I am bringing this up so we can have a broader discussion. We may disagree on how we should order, but I think that at the very least, `overrideConfigKey` and ``io.quarkus.test.junit.QuarkusUnitTest#getConfigOverrides` should be at the same ordinality.

> @radcortez This issue is about `QuarkusUnitTest` (from `quarkus-junit5-internal`) which IMO does not reflect the `QuarkusTestProfile` at all.

I know. Sorry for bringing this up here, I understand it may be confusing. I brought this up because recently, I've also encountered issues with `io. quarkus.test.junit.QuarkusUnitTest#getConfigOverrides`. They have very similar names, and in my opinion, they should behave in the same way, no matter which testing context you are in. 

> Currently, all of these config properties are backed by the same `ConfigSource` - the one used to load `application.properties`. Which is probably not a problem because test authors control the deployment structure.

Yes, I know. We could split each API into its own source with its own ordinality, making it clear who overrides who.

> > @radcortez This issue is about `QuarkusUnitTest` (from `quarkus-junit5-internal`) which IMO does not reflect the `QuarkusTestProfile` at all.> 
> I know. Sorry for bringing this up here, I understand it may be confusing. I brought this up because recently, I've also encountered issues with `io. quarkus.test.junit.QuarkusUnitTest#getConfigOverrides`. They have very similar names, and in my opinion, they should behave in the same way, no matter which testing context you are in.

No problem. You mean `QuarkusTestProfile#getConfigOverrides()`, right? Well, these are two completely separate APIs. So the names are similar but the use cases are very different.

> 
> > Currently, all of these config properties are backed by the same `ConfigSource` - the one used to load `application.properties`. Which is probably not a problem because test authors control the deployment structure.
> 
> Yes, I know. We could split each API into its own source with its own ordinality, making it clear who overrides who.

I would personally start with a minimum viable fix and javadoc clarification. And we could improve the things later :shrug:.

issue.title: QuarkusUnitTest: fix ignored overrideConfigKey()
issue.body:
- if the test archive already contains an "application.properties" asset
- also clarify the javadoc: overriden config properties take precedence
- reimplement withConfigurationResource() to use JavaArchive#addAsResource(resourceName, "application.properties") and  avoid the ordering inconsistency if both withConfigurationResource() and overrideConfigKey() are used
- fixes #43129
